a.style: font-family:'Playfair Display', Georgia, 'Times New Roman', 'Liberation Serif', serif;font-weight:500

text.tspan: Prevalence of modern contraception methods vs. average years of
Shown is the share of women who are practicing, or whose sexual partners are practicing, at least one modern method of
contraception. It is usually measured for women ages 15-49 who are married or in union.
Data source: Data compiled from multiple sources by World Bank, Barro and Lee (2015)
Note: Modern methods of contraception include female and male sterilization, oral hormonal pills, the intra-uterine device (IUD), condoms,
injectables, the implant (including Norplant), vaginal barrier methods, and female emergency contraception.
